analysisParams.promptTemplate: You are an analyst who specializes in summarizing social media content. Provide a concise summary of the main topics, themes, and sentiments in these tweets.

promptUsed.system: You are an analyst who specializes in summarizing social media content. Provide a concise summary of the main topics, themes, and sentiments in these tweets.
promptUsed.user:
Please analyze these tweets from @Dwarkesh Patel and provide a summary of what they mainly talked about in the past week:

Vibe coding -> muller's ratchet on codebase https://t.co/0I7PiR6jD3

@shae_mcl Congrats!!

If you enjoyed my episode with the physicist Adam Brown, you'll find this interesting.

Adam discussed the possibility of vacuum decay, where you change the laws of the accessible universe and potentially destroy it. 

Here is a survey of what other physicists think:

Watch the full episode with @JoHenrich:

Read the transcript:

https://t.co/7OdUh9yDPl

Apple Podcasts:

https://t.co/kYiZCnDmh9

Spotify:

https://t.co/hUFFcwKssu

YouTube:

https://t.co/DvDBcxKsQ3

With the decline in war, have we lost the selective pressure which makes governments improve over time?

There are many other layers of selection (companies within markets, political parties within elections).

But there's no ground truth outer loss on the system as a whole. https://t.co/a0HKHzvv0t

@cremieuxrecueil @StefanFSchubert Thanks for this @cremieuxrecueil @StefanFSchubert. 

I did push him on that Reich lab study to the best of my understanding at the time.

Read the transcript:
https://t.co/7OdUh9yDPl

Apple Podcasts:
https://t.co/kYiZCnDmh9

Spotify:
https://t.co/hUFFcwKssu

YouTube:
https://t.co/DvDBcxKsQ3

Humans have succeeded thanks to cultural evolution (and not individual IQ).

And that's precisely why I think AGI is *under hyped*.

Because of massive populations and perfect knowledge transfer, AGI hive minds will discover new ideas so much faster, whether from lucky mistakes, deliberate experiments, de-novo inventions, or some combination.

This will be a step-function increase in cultural evolution that was as big as the jump between humans and non-human primates. 

Full interview with @JoHenrich out now!

https://t.co/9XwHlJvSeQ

Read the transcript:
https://t.co/7OdUh9yDPl

Spotify:
https://t.co/hUFFcwKssu

Apple Podcasts: https://t.co/kYiZCnDmh9

YouTube: https://t.co/DvDBcxKsQ3

New ep with @JoHenrich!

Humans have *not* succeeded because of our raw intelligence. 

Marooned European explorers regularly starved to death in areas where foragers thrived for 1000s of years.

I‚Äôve always found this cultural evolution deeply mysterious.

How do you discover the 10 steps for processing cassava so it won‚Äôt give you cyanide poisoning simply by trial and error?

Has human brain size declined over the last 10,000 years because we outsourced cultural evolution to a larger collective brain?

The most interesting part of the podcast is Henrich‚Äôs explanation of how the Catholic Church unintentionally instigated the Industrial Revolution through the dismantling of intensive kinship systems in medieval Europe.

Links below. Enjoy!

Timestamps:
0:00:00 - Humans didn‚Äôt succeed because of raw IQ
0:10:13 - How cultural evolution works
0:21:34 - Why is brain size declining?
0:32:46 - Will AGI have superhuman cultural learning?
0:43:20 - Why the Industrial Revolution happened in Europe
0:56:16 - Why China, Rome, India got left behind
1:21:55 - Loss of cultural variance in modern world
1:32:06 - Is individual genius real?
01:44:35 - IQ and collective brains

This was really good. 

As you listen to these interesting nerd snipey arguments, it‚Äôs worth emphasizing that Will is describing something that is quite plausible in the next decade or two. 

They‚Äôre talking about our timeline folks!

Let @ashleevance know!

And subscribe to Core Memory!

@DanielleFong üòÇ

The most interesting part of the @JoHenrich interview was when he explained how the Catholic Church unintentionally caused the Industrial Revolution!

The Church wanted to acquire land and wealth that would otherwise remain within extended kinship networks. 

So they systematically dismantled these competing kin system of Early Medieval Europe. 

"By the high Middle Ages, you get the rise of guilds, which are voluntary groups of craftsmen and self-help societies, because people don't have their families to rely on.

People begin moving around, there's occupational sorting into different occupations, urbanization is rising, charter towns are on the rise, universities pop up, new kinds of monasteries pop up."

Full episode out tomorrow!

@willmacaskill @robertwiblin The faster the intelligence explosion, the longer the podcast!

You'll get to work with a hilarious, brilliant, intense gentleman scientist who has decoded ancient scrolls, plotted out a terraform of Mars, and is currently making cheap synthetic fuel from sunlight and air.

Why haven't you applied?

@adamvsteele To be clear, at no point do I think Mao was actually a great leader. The Communists winning the civil war was a tragedy. But it's a good quote!

‚ÄúHad Mao died in 1956, his achievements would have been immortal. Had he died in 1966, he would still have been a great man but flawed. But he died in 1976. Alas, what can one say?‚Äù

- Chen Yun, a leading Chinese Communist Party official under Mao and Deng Xiaoping

@amytcun oh no ... wasn't me this time right üëÄ

@sgrove I'm in! DMing

@s8mb Same thing with ordering. It doesn‚Äôt take 15 minutes to read a menu, but that‚Äôs how much most waiters will give you. 

My solution is to declare that I‚Äôm ready to order as we‚Äôre sitting down, even if I haven‚Äôt seen the menu.

summary: The main topics discussed by @Dwarkesh Patel in the past week include physics concepts such as vacuum decay, cultural evolution, AGI (Artificial General Intelligence), human success attributed to cultural evolution rather than raw intelligence, the Industrial Revolution, and the impact of the Catholic Church on history. The tweets also mention interviews with physicist Adam Brown and discussions on brain size decline, collective brains, and the potential of AGI hive minds. Overall, the sentiment seems to be intellectually curious and engaging with complex concepts.
